Authors:
Garrett Lee Beier, Stan C Hokanson, Scott T Bates, Robert A
Blanchette
Title:
Aurantiaporthe corni gen. et comb. nov., an endophyte and
pathogen of Cornus alternifolia
Keywords:
Cryphonectriaceae, Diaporthales, golden canker, pagoda
dogwood
Abstract:
Cryptodiaporthe corni is the causal agent of a destructive
disease of pagoda dogwood called golden canker. Due to the common
association between C. corni and pagoda dogwood, we wanted to determine
if the fungus is capable of living as an endophyte in pagoda dogwood.
Forty asymptomatic stems were sampled from five sites across Minnesota
and the fungus was found to be present in more than half (62.5%) of the
stems. Asymptomatic nursery material was also sampled, and a small
percentage (20%) had the fungus present. To determine if the endophytic
form of the fungus was capable of causing disease, inoculations were
carried out in the field and greenhouse. Asymptomatic stems in the field
that were inoculated with sterile grain seed proceeded to develop golden
canker as frequently as those that were inoculated with grain seed
colonized by C. corni. Also, in a greenhouse pathogenicity trial, the
isolate obtained from an asymptomatic stem was capable of causing
disease and KochÂ’s postulates, which has not been previously reported,
was completed. Since multiple specimens and isolates were collected
during this study another aspect of this research was to determine the
proper taxonomic place of C. corni. Phylogenetic studies over the last
decade have suggested that C. corni belongs in the Cryphonectriaceae
family. Phylogenetic analysis of the ITS and Bt1 gene regions, along
with assessment of the morphological characteristics supported the
creation of a new genus. Therefore we are proposing a new genus in the
Cryphonectriaceae family, Aurantiaporthe, to accommodate the new
combination Aurantiaporthe corni.
